Printing books in kanji instead of Roman alphabet can save trees, and here's why. 

1. The first reason is that kanji characters are more compact than Roman letters. A kanji character usually represents a complete word, whereas Roman letters typically only represent individual sounds. Therefore, printing books in kanji will require fewer pages than printing the same book in Roman letters, since more information can be conveyed in each character.

2. The second reason is that printing books in kanji reduces the need for translation. If a book is written in English and printed in the Roman alphabet, it may need to be translated into other languages if it is to be read by people who don't speak English. This means that multiple versions of the book must be printed, each with their own set of pages. However, if the book is written in kanji, it can be read by people who speak Japanese without any translation needed. Therefore, fewer copies of the book need to be printed overall, saving paper and trees.

3. Finally, it's worth noting that this conclusion assumes that the same content is being printed in both kanji and Roman letters. If the kanji version of the book has considerably more content than the Roman version, then it may require more pages to print, negating any positive environmental benefits. However, in general, using kanji instead of Roman letters for book printing is likely to save trees.
